structured_info.title_cn: 使用机器学习和特征选择的电信行业呼叫掉落动态分析系统
structured_info.title_en: A SYSTEM FOR ANALYSING CALL DROP DYNAMICS IN THE TELECOM INDUSTRY USING MACHINE LEARNING AND FEATURE SELECTION
structured_info.abstract: Quality of service in the telecom industry plays a vital role in the growth and economy of the country. In India, several telecom operators provide services, and there is a regulatory authority known as the Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI). In the telecom domain, call dropping is a problem that deteriorates the performance of the telecom industry in rendering services. It also causes inconvenience and waste of time for users, as well as reducing the level of user satisfaction. There is a need for a technology-driven analysis with the help of Artificial Intelligence (AI) to analyze call drop dynamics toward making well-informed decisions. The existing research revealed that Machine Learning (ML) helps analyze call drop dynamics. However, there is a need for a framework with machine learning techniques and optimizations to improve performance in analyzing call drop dynamics in the telecom industry. In this paper, we proposed an ML framework for automatic analysis of all drops in the telecom industry across all operators. The framework also supports optimizations like future engineering and dimensionality reduction to improve the performance of machine learning models. We proposed an algorithm called Learning based Call Drop Analytics (LbCDA) which exploits feature selection and training multiple classifiers towards call drop analytics. With benchmark dataset variants of the telecom industry, our empirical study has revealed that our framework's Random Forest (RF) model outperforms other models with the highest accuracy of 87.40 .
structured_info.methodology: The research employs a machine learning framework involving exploratory data analysis, feature engineering, dimensionality reduction (using Principal Component Analysis), and multiple classifiers including K-Nearest Neighbors, Support Vector Classifier, Gaussian Naive Bayes, Decision Tree, and Random Forest. The proposed Learning based Call Drop Analytics (LbCDA) algorithm uses feature selection and trains multiple classifiers for call drop prediction.
structured_info.conclusion: The proposed ML framework, particularly the Random Forest model, achieved the highest accuracy of 87.40% in call drop analytics, outperforming other models. This system can help telecom operators understand and mitigate call drop issues, improving service quality and user satisfaction. Future work includes enhancing the framework with deep learning models and hyperparameter tuning.
structured_info.venue: Journal of Theoretical and Applied Information Technology

analysis.Overview: The paper proposes a machine learning framework for analyzing call drop dynamics in the telecom industry, using feature selection, dimensionality reduction, and multiple classifiers to predict and mitigate call drops across various operators.
Background_and_Motivation: The research addresses the broader challenge of call drops in the telecom industry, which deteriorates service performance, causes user inconvenience, reduces satisfaction, and impacts economic growth.

Motivation stems from the need for AI-driven analysis to overcome limitations in existing approaches, as current research lacks comprehensive frameworks with optimizations for accurate call drop prediction.
The authors argue for necessity by highlighting regulatory oversight (e.g., TRAI) and the urgency to improve service quality using technology, emphasizing that call drops waste time and resources.

They relate the specific problem to broader challenges by discussing how call drops affect national economy and user experience, establishing significance through references to telecom industry growth and AI potential.
The paper contributes to the fields of Machine Learning and Telecommunications, with interdisciplinary applications in data analytics and network optimization.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Core concepts include: (1) Handoffs - defined as the process where a call's channel changes due to signal degradation or cell boundary crossing; (2) Cell Splitting - dividing large cells into smaller ones to reduce call drops; (3) Feature Selection - identifying key features to improve ML model training.
The logical relationship involves Handoffs leading to call drops, mitigated by Cell Splitting and Hybrid Channel Allocation; Feature Selection enhances ML models, which analyze data to predict drops.

Key assumptions include: telecom data can be effectively modeled with ML; features like signal strength and network type are representative; and optimizations like dimensionality reduction improve accuracy.
The paper makes an applied contribution by introducing a novel ML framework and LbCDA algorithm, advancing knowledge in predictive analytics for telecom service improvement.
Methodology: Core methods include supervised ML classifiers (KNN, SVC, GaussianNB, Decision Tree, Random Forest), feature selection via correlation analysis, dimensionality reduction with PCA, and the LbCDA algorithm for training multiple classifiers.

The methodology is novel for integrating feature engineering and optimizations like SMOTE for data balancing; it is applicable to telecom data and rational due to empirical validation showing improved accuracy.

Data sources involve a benchmark telecom dataset with features such as operator, network type, signal strength, and call drop categories; preprocessing includes handling missing values, encoding, and outlier removal. Representativeness is evaluated through exploratory data analysis showing operator-wise and category distributions.
Experimental design is rigorous with confusion matrix metrics (precision, recall, F1-score, accuracy); evaluation metrics are adequate, covering multi-class classification for call drop categories.
The research follows a data-driven paradigm, influenced by ML theory, which affects the perspective by focusing on empirical results and algorithmic solutions over theoretical models.
Results: Key results: Random Forest model achieved the highest accuracy of 87.40%, with precision, recall, and F1-scores detailed for call drop categories (e.g., 0.88 precision for poor voice quality); PCA visualizations showed clustering effects.

Results are significant as RF outperformed other models; reliability is supported by metrics like F1-score (e.g., 0.89 for poor voice quality), and stability is indicated through consistent performance across data variants (undersampled and oversampled datasets).
Argumentation_and_Logic: The argument structure includes: introduction to the problem, literature review, preliminaries, proposed framework, experimental results, and conclusion.
Key steps: define call drop issues, review prior work gaps, introduce ML framework and LbCDA algorithm, present empirical results, and conclude with implications.

Strengths include clear progression from problem to solution with empirical evidence; weaknesses are potential oversights in data limitations. Authors address rebuttals by comparing to existing methods and highlighting RF's superiority.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Strengths: Novel ML framework with optimizations, high accuracy (87.40%) with RF, and practical algorithm LbCDA for feature selection.
Limitations: Methodology boundaries include reliance on specific datasets and ML models; limitations involve data insufficiency and lack of deep learning integration.
The choice of data-driven paradigm constrains conclusions to empirical validations, potentially overlooking broader network dynamics or theoretical models.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: The paper engages in the ML and telecom discourse by building on prior work (e.g., citing Lalwani et al. and Ullah et al.) to position its framework as filling a research gap.

Terminology includes technical terms like 'feature selection', 'dimensionality reduction', and 'Random Forest'; tone is formal and persuasive; rhetorical strategies emphasize innovation and empirical success.

Authors build authority through extensive citations (20+ references) to establish context, with motivations including validating their approach against existing literature and promoting AI in telecom.
Conclusions_and_Implications: Main conclusions: The ML framework effectively analyzes call drops, with RF achieving 87.40% accuracy; optimizations like feature engineering enhance performance, offering telecom operators tools for service improvement.
Future research insights: Improve framework with deep learning and hyperparameter tuning; suggestions include addressing data limitations and exploring real-time analytics for broader applications.
